thread.title: So closes in on No. 1 world ranking
thread.title_full: So closes in on No. 1 world ranking

title: So closes in on No. 1 world ranking
text:
So closes in on No. 1 world ranking Joey Villar   3:37pm 
MANILA, Philippines â€“ Filipino-born GM Wesley So left the Philippines for the United States a few years back to chase a dream of becoming world champion. 
That dream is starting to become a reality. Related Stories So draws anew, keeps half-point lead 
Playing his best chess to date, So, 23, topped the Tata Steel Masters 2017 in Wijk aan Zee, Netherlands Sunday night against a field that included reigning World Champion GM Magnus Carlsen of Norway and his challenger GM Sergey Karjakin of Russia to zoom to No. 2 in the world in terms of rating. 
So won it by scoring an unbeaten nine points on five victories, including a smashing 28-move triumph over Russian GM Ian Nepomniachtchi of a Trompovsky Attack in the 13th and final round, and eight draws. 
The proud son of Cavite finished a full point ahead of Carlsen, who drew with Karjakin, to gain 14.1 points that propelled the former to No. 2 in the world with a live rating of 2822.1, second only to Carlsen's 2838.3. 
It was So's first victory in the annual tournament after finishing sixth in 2014 and third in 2015 and last year. 
National Chess Federation of the Phl's acting executive director Red Dumuk said it is a proud accomplishment for the country. 
"It's something we should celebrate because Wesley So is born in the Philippines and still a Filipino even though he now represents the United States," said Dumuk, who is also the NCFP treasurer and deputy secretary-general. 
So has been playing spectacular chess in the past few months as he is currently on a 56-game unbeaten streak. 
He also topped the Sinquefield Cup in St. Louis, Missouri and helped the US reign supreme in the 42nd Olympiad in Baku, Azerbaijan while winning the Board Three individual gold medal on the side last year. 
Now the sky is the limit for So, who is gunning to earn a shot at Carlsen's title with the Championship cycle starting this year.
